title: 107_hr504
content: The Act titled "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" is for the purpose of providing access to healthcare services. The Act aims to assist communities and health care providers in developing integrated health care delivery systems for uninsured and underinsured individuals, through coordination of services, infrastructure development, and provision of new Federal resources. The Act aims to develop integrated health care delivery systems through effective collaboration, information sharing, and provision of new Federal resources without supplanting existing funding for low-income populations. The Public Health Service Act is amended to create a Community Access Program that provides grants to enhance services for the uninsured and underinsured. The Secretary may grant funds to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals, expanding services, and enhancing efficiency among providers. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit organizations like Federally qualified health centers and hospitals meeting specific criteria. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals must be Federally qualified health centers, hospitals meeting specific criteria, or public health departments. They should represent a consortium of providers focused on delivering coordinated health care services to defined communities. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals must represent a consortium of providers focused on delivering coordinated health care services to defined communities, including special population groups. Entities eligible for grants to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals must represent a consortium of providers focused on delivering coordinated health care services to defined communities, including special population groups. Preference is given to health care providers identified in the application process. To be eligible for a grant, an entity must define a community of uninsured and underinsured individuals, identify participating providers, and describe planned activities. The consortium applying for the grant must describe their program contributions to uninsured and underinsured individuals, including care volume for different patient groups, activities proposed to further the grant's purposes, ability to involve providers serving the community, and ability to develop coordinated systems of care. The consortium applying for the grant must demonstrate their ability to involve providers serving the community, develop coordinated systems of care, ensure community involvement in program development, and enroll participants in public insurance programs. The consortium applying for the grant must involve the community in program development, ensure participants are enrolled in public insurance programs, leverage other funding sources for sustainability, evaluate program activities, and demonstrate fiscal responsibility. The grant applicants must involve the community in program development, enroll participants in public insurance programs, leverage funding sources for sustainability, evaluate program activities, demonstrate fiscal responsibility, and prioritize applicants with public hospitals and Federally qualified health centers in their consortium. The Secretary may prioritize grant applicants with public hospitals and Federally qualified health centers in their consortium, those serving uninsured individuals, and communities with a high percentage of uninsured individuals. The program criteria include identifying communities with a high percentage of uninsured individuals, involving health care providers with a history of serving the uninsured, expanding preventive and primary care services, improving coordination between health care and social service providers. The program criteria for grants include improving coordination between health care and social service providers, collaborating with state and local governments, utilizing non-Federal contributions, and ensuring program sustainability. The program criteria for grants include improving coordination between health care and social service providers, collaborating with state and local governments, utilizing non-Federal contributions, and ensuring program sustainability. Grantees may use funds for direct expenses associated with planning, developing, and operating a health care delivery system that provides a broad range of services, including substance abuse treatment and mental health services, as well as for direct patient care and service. The grant funds can be used for a variety of purposes, such as increasing outreach activities, improving case management, and coordinating transportation to healthcare facilities. The grant funds can be used for various purposes, including increasing outreach activities, improving case management, coordinating transportation to healthcare facilities, developing provider networks, recruiting and training personnel, acquiring technology, closing gaps in services, and enhancing provider communication. The grant funds can be used for various purposes, such as closing gaps in services, improving provider communication, and increasing access to the uninsured. No more than 15 percent of the funds can be used for direct patient care, and the Secretary may reserve up to 3 percent for national program purposes. No more than 15 percent of the funds can be used for direct patient care, and the Secretary may reserve up to 3 percent for national program purposes, including technical assistance, expert consultation, and program evaluation. Maintenance of effort is required for grant recipients and participating providers to maintain their expenditures of non-Federal funds for grant activities. The Secretary may award a grant under this section only if the recipient and participating providers agree to maintain their non-Federal fund expenditures at or above the previous year's level. Recipients must report annually to the Secretary on goal progress and provide any additional information requested. Renewal of annual grants is contingent on compliance with these requirements. The recipient of a grant must report annually to the Secretary on progress towards grant goals and provide any additional information required. Renewal of grants is dependent on meeting the goals set forth in the grant application. Entities receiving grants must undergo an independent annual financial audit. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to funded entities as needed. The section requires an independent annual financial audit of grant funds. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to funded entities. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006.
